Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Type 2: Collaborative Research: A Computational and Analytic Laboratory for Modeling and Predicting Marine Biodiversity and Indicators of Sustainable Ecosystems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Marine ecosystems are complex and variable networks of interacting organisms that support roughly half of global productivity and play important roles in sustaining global processes. The lower trophic levels that are the focus of this project include primary producers at the base of the food web, as well as bacteria and a variety of small grazers that turn over rapidly and provide links that transfer energy to higher trophic levels, such as fish, seabirds, and marine mammals, helping to maintain healthy ecosystems. Mounting recognition points to the societal value of not just timely information about the status and change of marine ecosystems but how well we can model and predict them. While existing and emerging observation systems are poised to contribute, there is a large need for computationally-enabled marine biodiversity data and information systems. Despite recognition as system-level science, the way specialists and non-specialists think about ecosystems must move from reducing the problem spaces into specialized and finer partitions to a significantly more integrative and predictive one. This research effort brings together computational and information scientists, oceanographers and microbiologists to develop a Marine Biodiversity Virtual Laboratory (MBVL). In addition to research investigations of marine ecosystems, the Virtual Laboratory provides a platform for education via student diversity programs at the three institutions. The important learning opportunities will be two-fold for students: (1) to learn about, model, and make predictions for biodiversity in natural systems, and (2) to be exposed to working in an interdisciplinary team that includes both natural scientists and computer scientists. The project aims to foster a new generation of data scientists with skills that can cross disciplines. There will be capabilities to trace, verify and trust the original data and model sources that comprise key indicators of diversity as part of ecosystem health; this has become a requirement for technical (and societal) implementations. MBVL will contain a knowledge base for such indicators. While this is essential for research, the MBVL will also enhance education as students will truly probe, question, explore and experiment with the health, risks, and possible changes in specific marine environments.

MBVL will address multi-scale, heterogeneous data challenges with informatics solutions that enable the cyber-generation and documentation of biodiversity indicators, providing the traceability between data and information to be used as a basis for sustainable ecosystem-based management and needed policy decisions. Thus researchers and students will be further engaged to think and act at the system-level. The research will have impacts beyond ocean sciences, i.e. more broadly in management and policymaking regarding marine resources and ecosystem services via key links with fisheries managers enabled by collaborations external to this project and with industry partners to evaluate and disseminate solutions to a much wider user base.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mounting recognition points to the societal value of not just timely information about the status and change of marine ecosystems but how well we can model and predict them. While existing and emerging observation systems are poised to contribute, there was a large need for computationally-enabled marine biodiversity data and information systems. This research effort brought together a distributed team of computational and information scientists, oceanographers, and microbiologists to develop a Marine Biodiversity Virtual Laboratory (MBVL). The MBVL has enabled transformative access to and integration of ocean observations to produce novel science insights into marine ecosystems and the services they provide. The approach addressed large scale, heterogeneous data challenges with informatics solutions that enabled the cyber-generation and documentation of biodiversity indicators, provided the traceability between data and information as a basis for sustainable ecosystem-based management and needed policy decisions. Accomplishments are detailed below for specific objectives of the project.

Major outcomes:

- development and implementation of provenance workflows for data products in (especially in relation to OBIS efforts – broader impacts) and completion of B. Lee’s PhD Thesis

- data products: Major outcome on automated classification for target data type “Image data for phytoplankton” from our proposal was described in the WHOI report.

- collaboration with WHOI colleagues in the development of an intermediate data model to contribute IFCB data products to community repositories addressing Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) principles;

- development of the VersOn ontology for data product change

- documentation of versioning in the data product pipeline

- traceable workflows: With undergraduate student Katherine Qi WHOI and RPI personnel developed a workflow to (visualize and) publish IFCB data products relevant to the Group On Earth Observations Biodiversity Observation Network (GEO BON) Essential Biodiversity Variables (EBVs) and Global Ocean Observing System (GOOS) Essential Ocean Variables (EOVs). 

- RPI Graduate students Benno Lee and Akshay Bhaisin provided provenance-based models () for these workflows. A key aspect of the workflows was their versioning. Lee’s thesis (see reference/ products) directly addressed this. 

- Bhaisin’s work directly transferred to the OBIS community via WHOI investigators. Figs. 2a, b, and c display the schema models developed (and adopted) in the process.

Dissemination to our peers as journal articles, conference presentations, and other products. Additional dissemination to peers included presentation and software demo at WHOI’s Summer Student Fellow Symposium in August 2019 and completion of the RPI summer internship work (Bhaisin). 

Beyond the ocean sciences, there are clear positive impacts in biodiversity science more broadly inclusive of Earth systems, important for the Group On Earth Observations Biodiversity Observation Network (GEO BON) Essential Biodiversity Variables (EBVs). We expanded our efforts to include a use case for the Environmental Data Initiative repository, which generally serves terrestrial ecologists. Project outcomes include a cyber-enabled, scalable, open-source, standards-based framework that can be applied to biodiversity data from any ecosystem. 

Lee’s thesis contribution of the VersOn ontology has been to be adopted as semantic infrastructure in subsequent Tetherless World projects. Result from Lee’s thesis not related to this project - NASA Global Change Master Directory, version change log trace and Deep Carbon Observatory, Noble Gas Isotope version change/ control log (versions, 1, 2 and 3) were shared with the dataset authors.
